The first is the political faction, Yemenâs [[Muslim Brotherhood]], led by [[Mohammed Qahtan]]. The third is the mainstream [[Salafi|Salafists]] in Yemen, led by the countryâs most prominent Sunni religious scholar, [[Abdul Majeed al-Zindani]]."[http://www.stratfor.com/yemen_election_realignment Yemen: An Election Realignment] STRATFOR, September 20, 2006 In the [[Yemeni parliamentary election, 2003|2003 parliamentary election]], Al-Islah won 46 seats. {{As of|2010}}, 13 of Al-Islah's [[Assembly of Representatives (Yemen)|parliament]] members are women, including human rights activist and Nobel laureate [[Tawakel Karman]],{{cite web |last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=The United States & Yemen â Destroying Lives in the Name of National Security|work=|publisher=Brecht Forum|date=2010|url=http://brechtforum.org/civicrm/event/info?id=11729|format=|doi=|accessdate=2011-02-01|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wBGBE8nf|archivedate=2011-02-01|deadurl=no}} who created the activist group Women Journalists Without Chains in 2005{{cite web | last =Al-Sakkaf| first =Nadia| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Renowned activist and press freedom advocate Tawakul Karman to the Yemen Times: "A day will come when all human rights violators pay for what they did to Yemen" | work =| publisher =Women Journalists Without Chains| date =2010-06-17| url =http://womenpress.org/articles.php?id=309 |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8NYbYFU |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }} and became the first Yemeni and Arab woman to win the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 2011. ==Policies== ===National=== Al-Islah party says that those thinking of fighting for the Yemeni government against the [[Sa'dah insurgency]] of the [[Houthis]], should instead keep well out of the war because Yemenis must not help Yemenâs pro-Western government, which deserves to be overthrown.{{cite news | first=Mazrak | last=Camp | pages= | language =| title=Yemen's War - Pity those caught in the middle | date=2009-11-19 | publisher=[[The Economist]] | url=http://www.economist.com/node/14920092?story_id=14920092 |accessdate=2011-02-16 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wY4End4c |archivedate=2011-02-16 |deadurl=no }} Al-Islah is agitating, at the moment, against a draft amendment to the [[constitution of Yemen]] that could allow the president to run for life.
